name: Homepage
bodyOriginal:
Our innovative product mix of magazines, trade shows, directories and books, web sites and electronic media arms the cosmetic, personal-care, salon and spa, and perfume and flavor industries with 80 years of knowledge and experience along with a wealth of information.

    Fueled by creative, dedicated employees, Allured Publishing Corporation remains a leader in high quality editorial, cutting edge information, and company wide responsive customer service. We embrace the industry challenges of tomorrow by constantly evolving in technology, product development and growth to suit the needs of our domestic and international customers and advertisers.

    Through our strong, expert network, both internal and external, combined with global market visibility and accessibility, we are committed to excellence. We are committed to you.

    We thank you for your interest in Allured Publishing Corporation, if you would like more information about our products, magazines, or industry news and events, please feel free to browse any of the pages that interest you. For your convenience, we offer user friendly on-line subscribing and product purchasing. Visit our web site often, as it will be updated with news and exciting new books and products. We value our customers and welcome your comments or questions.

Sincerely, Allured Publishing Corporation

name: Events
bodyOriginal:
Shows & Conferences

Allured develops trade shows and conferences each year to bring the latest live training to readers of its various magazines. These shows enable attendees to keep abreast of the most useful techniques and network with colleagues in order to make them and their businesses successful in today's competitive marketplace.

 
 
Face & Body Spa & Healthy Aging Conference and Exhibition, drives the industry toward a total body rejuvenation approach to healthy aging. This is the only industry event that offers a forum to connect spa industry professionals with their colleagues who serve the healthy aging, wellness, personal care, fitness, cosmetic and nutrition industries. The exclusive, multi-track education program will drive attendees toward expansion of their business to align with the trend toward younger living and healthy aging.
 
 
  America's Expo for Skin Care & Spa Chicago, created exclusively for skin and spa professionals, is a European-style expo with a setting similar to an actual spa and offers intensive education on the latest treatments and techniques. See the newest products from your favorite skin care manufacturers.

name: Magazines
bodyOriginal:
Magazines

Allured's strength has always been in our line of top-ranked industry magazines. We pride ourselves in providing you with the latest information authored by industry experts. Each title has a unique blend of content targeted to its specific industry needs.

 
.
 
Cosmetics & Toiletries magazine presents a full range of products covering the international cosmetic technology field - including the magazine, a tradeshow, conferences, books and a web site. The monthly magazine brings the most current technologies in formulating, research, regulations and new ingredients. Read Cosmetics & Toiletries for the latest ingredient innovations. Gain practical formulating advice, read about the new hair and skin research, keep on top of international regulations, and see how trends impact product development.

To subscribe to Cosmetics & Toiletries magazine contact us at 1-630-653-2155 or email customerservice@allured.com. Click here to subscribe online.
  .
 

Global Cosmetic Industry is a monthly business magazine for the cosmetics and personal care industry. In covers current issues, product categories and market trends. Columnists drawn from the industry and share their expertise in every issue. GCI covers industry segments including cosmetics, toiletries, fine fragrance, soaps and personal cleansers, and home products including soaps, cleaners and home fragrances.

To subscribe to GCI magazine call 815-734-1225. Click here to subscribe online.

Cosmetics & Toiletries, along with sister publication Global Cosmetic Industry, also provides an extensive online information resource called TheCosmeticSite.com which provides the latest news on people, companies, the market and new technologies. It is a resource for finding companies, consultants, testing laboratories and other frequently needed organizations for the industry.

 

 
 
Skin Inc. magazine  is a monthly business management magazine for owners, managers and estheticians at skin care salons and spas. It covers industry news, business practices, innovative treatments, techniques and products. The magazine produces the annual tradeshow, Face & Body, Spa & Healthy Aging Conference and Exhibition. The show focuses on business development and expansion, and education. The magazine web site, www.SkinInc.com, provides up-to-date industry news and events and a database of current and prior articles. The show web site, www.faceandbody.com, provides year long worldwide exposure to exhibitions.

Enjoy Skin Inc. for business and marketing tips, step-by-step treatment recipes and "how-to" articles, a calender of events and educational opportunities, regular columns, and an annual directory to the industry - a $25 value - free with your subscription.

To subscribe to Skin Inc. magazine, contact us at 1-800-469-7445 or 1-815-734-1147. Click here to subscribe online.
   
 
Perfumer & Flavorist magazine  is a bimonthly magazine for the international fragrance and flavor market. It covers the technology, the art, and the psychology of flavor and fragrance development. Perfumer & Flavorist magazine bring books, conferences and an extensive library of electronic research databases to the industry. The web site, www.PerfumerFlavorist.com, provides breaking industry news, a calendar of events, an industry supplier directory and an index of articles from current and prior magazine issues.

Enjoy P&F for the industry technology, science, news, events and people to watch for.

To subscribe to Perfumer & Flavorist contact us at 1-630-653-2155 or email customerservice@allured.com. Click here to subscribe online.
   
 
The Journal of Essential Oil Research is a scientific journal devoted to all facets of pure and applied studies on essential oils and plant volatiles.

Enjoy JEOR for the research reports, notes, and letters; and also for the reviews and techniques offered.

To subscribe contact us at 1-630-653-2155 or customerservice@allured.com.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Accounts Payable
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Accounts Payable

Q. I received my credit card statement and there is a charge here from Allured Publishing. What is this for?

A. You may have charged a magazine subscription, magazine single copy, book, attended a conference or show and charged the entry fee, paid for a class at Face & Body or paid for advertising. Those charges show up as Allured Publishing, not as the individual product you may have purchased.

Q. I recently subscribed to your magazine and I have a question about the charge on my credit card statement. Who do I contact?

A. Account Receivable for Subscriptions is handled by Customer Service. Please supply us with complete details such as:

  • the dollar amount that was charged.
  • the date the amount was processed.
  • mail us a copy of your statement.

Please explain why you are disputing the amount.

Q. Why is there a duplicate charge on my credit card statement?

A. The reason may be because you sent in more than one payment. We process each order we receive. To avoid duplication, please do not, for instance, fax in an order with a credit card payment, and then mail in the order with a credit card payment. We process each order because there are many instances where customers wish to purchase more than one book or to add another copy of a subscription for the year. If you find a duplicate payment that you did not intend to purchase, please bring this to our attention and we will refund the charge.

Q. I paid one amount for my subscription but when I cancelled I was refunded only a portion of my payment. Why?

A. Because we refund on all unserved issues only. If you paid for a one year subscription to one of our magazines, and then cancel several months later, the unserved issues are refunded only. Also, we would appreciate hearing why you cancelled and we encourage any comments you may have.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Address/Name Change
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Address/Name Change

Q. If I move, who do I contact about my change of address?

A. We don’t want you to miss an issue! You may contact Customer Service for any address change by clicking here. Don’t forget to notify your local post office of the change of address. We ask that you give us at least 30 –60 days notification so that you receive the issue at your new address if the post office is not forwarding your mail. In some cases, the issue has already been sent out to the old address and you may ‘claim’ the issue. Please see the Customer Service Claims Page and follow that procedure for a quicker response.

Q. There is a name change at my company - how do I change the name that appears on my current subscription?

A. If there is a name change on a company account, we would like this in writing on company stationary for our records. Please include the subscription number which is found on the address label beside or above the name.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Book Ordering
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Book Ordering

Q. How do I order your books?

A. There are six ways to order:

  • The simplest, fastest, and most efficient way to order is through our online store, which is a secured site.
  • Call Customer Service direct at 630-653-2155.
  • E-mail Customer Service.
  • Fax Customer Service at 630-653-2487.
  • Mail your order to:
    Allured Publishing Corp.
    362 S Schmale Rd.
    Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787
    c/o Customer Service.
    Include payment and order form or a print out of the on-line order form.
  • The last way to order is by requesting a Proforma Invoice for those products you wish to purchase. Once you return a copy of the Proforma Invoice with your payment, we will ship out your products.

Use e-mail or fax at your own risk when sending credit card information as this is not the recommended way to order. Please choose one way to order and order only once to avoid duplication.

Q. I placed an order for one of your books. Why haven't I heard from you?

A. As much as we would like to confirm each and every order that comes to us, it would be impossible to do so because of the volume we receive on a daily basis. If you do not receive your book after 8 - 10 weeks, we encourage you to e-mail us and let us know. If you placed an order, make sure that you included payment because we will only process your order with prepayment. Please do not send in another order or a copy of your order as it may be entered again and duplicated. More importantly, you will be charged twice because we have no way of knowing if your order is a duplicate.

Q. I ordered a book and received the wrong one. What do I do?

A. We are sorry about that. Please contact Customer Service.

Q. I am an advertiser and have not received my issue of the magazine that I advertised in. Who do I contact?

A. Please contact the editor of the magazine or the account representative.

Q. I am looking for a book, but I cannot locate it on your web site (or no longer have the book on the web site). Do you list all the books you sell?

A. Yes, we do. The web site is the best source of information for the current books we sell. Sometimes the book may be available on the web site one day and may be so popular that it sells out quickly. In this case, we may either send you a letter stating that the book is no longer available and return your payment or back order for you if we know the book is coming soon.

Q. I placed an order for a book. Why didn't you confirm my order?

A. As soon as we receive your payment and order we try to process it same day or next day. We do not confirm orders because of the high volume we receive daily. Please allow for the time it takes for your check to arrive at our office, processing, and delivery time (depending upon what type of delivery you chose). You will only hear from us if your credit card has declined or other reasons such as the book is no longer in stock.

Q. I placed an order for a book and have not received it yet. How long does it take?

A. That depends on what type of delivery option you chose. If you mailed your order and payment to us, please allow time for us to receive your order and processing. If you are located in the U.S., the delivery time is 7-10 business days. If you are international and you chose regular airmail service, your delivery time could take 6-8 weeks and is not trackable. The recommended shipping option for international is to use Courier Service for delivery in 10-15 business days and is trackable.

Q. What is your policy on returning books?

A. Due to the highly technical content of the books, they are sold on a non-refundable, non-returnable basis. We urge our customers to visit our online bookstore for a summary of the book and table of contents. If you have any further questions about the book, please call Customer Service and we will be happy to fax you a few pages from the book if you are uncertain about the content.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Claims
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Claims

Q. I have a one year subscription and I am missing an issue/issues. What is your claims policy?

A. Policy: A claims form must be filled out completely and then faxed, e-mailed or mailed to Customer Service, Claims Dept., 362 S. Schmale Rd., Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787. Our fax number is 630.653.2487. Claims for missing issues must be made within three months of the date issued - domestic. For international claims, the claim for missing issues must be made within six months or we will not replace the issues. Please do not wait until the end of the year to place your claims.

We can replace up to three issues per year only once. If an issue is out of print, we cannot replace. Please allow 8-10 weeks to receive issues from the date order or claim is received. If claims are made too early, we cannot replace issues and customer must claim again within a reasonable period of time. If you paid by wire transfer, please note that wire transfers and delivery can take up to three months to complete.

Q. I am not receiving many of the issues even though I paid for a one or two year subscription. What can I do?

A. We are sorry you are not receiving your issues. If you have gone through all the steps (see claims policy) then we suggest that you use an alternative shipping address. You can choose an address of someone you know from the United States or a different country and have your issues forwarded to you.

Q. How soon can I expect my issue to be replaced if I sent in the claim form?

A. You should have a replacement issue in 6-8 weeks providing:

  • Your address is correct.
  • Enough time has passed since the magazine was shipped out.

If the replacement issue does not arrive, perhaps, an alternative address may be the answer.

Q. I e-mailed Customer Service but I have not received an answer yet about my claim.

A. A claims form must be filled out and investigated by Customer Service. We cannot determine whether or not we can replace issues unless the form is completely filled out.

Q. Can you track my issues and find out why we are not receiving issues?

A. Unfortunately, we can only track the issue within the United States. Once it leaves our country, there is no tracking capabilities. In order for us to have tracking capabilities, we would have to substantially raise the cost of the subscription.

name: Websites
bodyOriginal:
Web Sites

Allured embraces all new technologies for the value they can add to our customers' business needs, and the Internet is no exception. Each of our business divisions has developed a world-class Web site associated with its magazine, CD-ROM, research, and exposition products. We invite you to visit our sites and let us know if there is anything we can add to them to make them more useful to you!

TheCosmeticSite.com
What if there was a place where you could get breaking industry news on international events, new ingredient and product launches, along with a forum to discuss all of it. What if this same place provided cosmetic technology information and sped up research efforts. Would you go to that place? Now you can at TheCosmeticSite.com.

As the premiere Web site for the cosmetic industry, TheCosmeticSite.com is paving the way for the industry on the Internet. Now is your chance to get in on this exciting project before anyone else. The CosmeticSite.com — the one stop site for and about the cosmetic industry!

Cosmetic Bench Reference Online
The Cosmetic Bench Reference Online research tool is an interactive database for cosmetic chemists that provides ingredient, formula and supplier information. As a member, this tool allows you to search for an ingredient and find formulas with that ingredient using the following criteria: Ingredient Name, Supplier Name, Formula Name, Mixture Name, Function of Ingredient, Formula Category, Formula Purpose, CAS #, EINECS, JCLS #, ELINCS, and CI #.

The Cosmetic Bench Reference Online also offers access to the suppliers who can provide you with any additional information you might need. It provides you with the ability to save your searched information in your own personalized notebook! - a feature that cuts down on doing things twice.


PerfumerFlavorist.com
The sweet smell of success is only a click away. PerfumerFlavorist.com, the Web site of Perfumer & Flavorist magazine, presents the latest in flavor and fragrance information and technology, along with accurate, up-to-date industry news. In addition to this, you will also have special access to Allured’s Flavor and Fragrance Materials, an industry contact directory, Allured’s Perfumer's Compendium and much, much more.

All in all, PerfumerFlavorist.com is the essential industry site for those looking to find an edge in their profession. PerfumerFlavorist.com — helping you smell success everyday!


Flavor and Fragrance Materials Online
Allured's Flavor and Fragrance Materials Online is a comprehensive international directory of materials used in the creation of flavors and fragrances. It includes relevant identifying and regulatory information for flavor and fragrance materials and all known suppliers of each material are included. The directory is fully searchable by the following fields: Flavor Materials, Fragrance Materials, Cosmetic Materials, Supplier, FDA, FEMA, CoE, Flash Pt., CAS, EINECS, FCC, FMA, and many more!

If you are looking to speed up your research by using a directory that is updated regulary, then Flavor and Fragrance Materials Online is perfect for you!


Perfumer's Compendium
Allured's Perfumer's Compendium allows you to search for fragrance materials by up to four odor descriptors, trade name/common name and supplier. On this database you will find information on more than 1,500 fragrance materials from 16 suppliers, including CAS #, FEMA #, flash point, use level and more. There is also a comments section that includes best use recommendations placed by the industry's leading product suppliers.

The Perfumer's Compendium features direct links to supplier companies to save you even more time - just another tool from Allured that can make you more effecient in your job!


SkinInc.com
The future of the salon and spa industry is right here — today! SkinInc.com offers the most complete, most accurate and most up-to-date information for everyone in the skin care industry, from spa owners to manufacturers. In addition to exclusive industry information, SkinInc.com is an invaluable tool when researching the latest techniques and licensing requirements in our ever-changing industries. In the market for a new job? Trade show updates, classified section, advertisement information and much, much more is all right here. SkinInc.com — the future is here today!


FaceandBody.com
Informative, Practical & Convenient — that sums up faceandbody.com. With trade shows playing a more important role in the skin care industry than ever before, it is essential to pick your shows wisely. At faceandbody.com, you can check out the presenters and read the session topics for the upcoming show, as well as see what companies and organizations will be exhibiting.

After reviewing this information, you can register online and schedule your entire trip before entering the exhibit hall. It’s easy, useful and will give you a distinct advantage when you attend the show. faceandbody.com — helping you get the most out the best show in the business.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Delivery
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Delivery

Q. What are your Delivery Options?

A. In order to serve you better, we are now offering several new options for shipping and handling of your purchases:

  • Courier Service: $40 (Recommended)
    International and Canada only.
    Phone number is required for Courier delivery. No PO Boxes please.
  • Canadian Delivery: $10
    Standard delivery in 7-10 business days after payment is received.
    Phone number is required for delivery. No PO Boxes please.
  • United States Delivery: $8
    Standard delivery in 7-10 business days after payment is received.
    Phone number is required for delivery. No PO Boxes please.

Note: We do not recommend International Airmail for $15 because it can take up to 12 weeks for delivery.

Please indicate the type of service you require on your order form, and include payment with your order.

Q. I chose International Airmail for $15.00. Why is delivery taking so long?

A. This is regular airmail and not courier service. This means that the delivery is not trackable and can be routed through several countries before it reaches you. There are cases where a book can take 12 weeks to reach international destinations. We cannot be held responsible for lost or stolen articles on this type of service. If you would like to receive your books within a reasonable length of time, please choose Courier Service which is more money, but we are able to guarantee delivery of your order.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: General Questions
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: General Questions

Q. I e-mailed Customer Service but I have not received an answer yet. What is taking so long?

A. Customer Service receives a great deal of e-mail on a daily basis. Some questions can be answered quickly. Other questions require further investigation by the department such as claims or wire transfer questions and may take a little longer to reply or may have to be forwarded to other departments. We will do our best to reply as quickly as possible. Claims and shipping concerns are processed on a weekly basis and your patience is greatly appreciated. If you do not hear from us within a reasonable length of time, please e-mail us again. There are times when e-mails directed to Customer Service are not received due to any number of reasons and there are times when we respond to e-mails only to discover the e-mails were never received. Allured Publishing deems each e-mail important and we will do our best to reply as quickly as possible and satisfy our customers.

Q. I would like to receive a catalog of your books and magazines. Who can I contact?

A. For book information please feel free to visit our online bookstore. Here you will find an updated list of all our products, with descriptions and a table of contents.

For magazine information, please visit the magazine site, where you will find a great deal of information.

Q. Why don't you provide Paid Invoices with every order?

A. We require prepayment on every order, therefore, we are not set up to handle systematic invoicing. If you require a Paid Invoice or a Proforma Invoice, you may request one. We provide a packing slip/paid invoice for each order.

bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics &Toiletries: Magazine Ordering

Q. How do I order a subscription to your magazine?

A. There are six ways to order:

  • The simplest, fastest, and most efficient way to order is through our online store, which is a secured site.
  • Call Customer Service direct at 630-653-2155.
  • E-mail Customer Service.
  • Fax Customer Service at 630-653-2487.
  • Mail your order to:
    Allured Publishing Corp.
    362 S Schmale Rd.
    Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787
    c/o Customer Service.
    Include payment and order form or a print out of the on-line order form.
  • The last way to order is by requesting a Proforma Invoice for those products you wish to purchase. Once you return a copy of the Proforma Invoice with your payment, we will ship out your products.

Use e-mail or fax at your own risk when sending credit card information as this is not the recommended way to order. Please choose one way to order and order only once to avoid duplication.

Q. Can I order specific issues of your magazines?

A.   You can order through Customer Service. If you would like to order a back issue(s), please specify:
  • The Name of the publication.
  • The Month you wish to order.
  • The Year you wish to order.

If you need assistance in determining which issue, please e-mail the editor of the magazine you are interested in. Please allow 2-3 weeks for shipping after payment is received. Back Issues are subject to availability. Prices are subject to change without notice. For all orders please add shipping and handling charges.

Q. I have never seen your magazine. Can you send me a sample issue? Can I request a specific issue?

A. We would be more than happy to send you a sample issue. Please e-mail 
CustomerService@allured.com with the following information:
  • The Name of the publication
  • Your name and complete shipping information
  • Phone Number
  • Business and Function at the company

A specific issue cannot be requested. For your convenience, we will send you an order form along with the sample issue. If you decide not to subscribe, please send back the order form. We would greatly appreciate your feedback and would like to know the reason you have decided not to subscribe. Please allow 4-6 weeks for a sample issue due to the high volume of requests we receive daily.

name: CSI: Cosmetics & Toiletries: Payment Options
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Payment Options

Q. What forms of payment do you accept?

A. All orders must be prepayed - you may pay by:

  • Visa
  • Mastercard
  • American Express
  • Check or Money Order
  • For International destinations a check drawn from a US bank in US dollars will be acceptable.
  • Wire transfers - please see details to the right.

Please note: we cannot accept Foreign Checks or Sterling payment.

Q. Why don’t you provide Paid Invoices with every order?

A. We require prepayment on every order, therefore, we are not set up to handle systematic invoicing. If you require a Paid Invoice or a Proforma Invoice, you may request one.

A packing slip/paid invoice is provided with each order for books.

Q. I am an international customer and we do not use credit cards. Can I set up a wire transfer to pay for my subscription?

A. Wire transfers will be accepted in the amount of US$100 or more. The information is as follows:

1. Customers in Europe may pay in US dollars from any bank in Europe via SWIFT (ABNANL2A) transfer into our US dollars account 40.54.19.805 at AMRO BANK, Afd. Zaken, AB 1050, Postbus 407, 1000 AK Amsterdam, Netherlands. IBAN: NL17ABNA0405419805

2. All wire transfers may be made through BANK ONE, (071000013), Chicago, Illinois 60690. Our account number is: 20000057. SWIFT: FNBCUS44

Please fill out the Wire Transfer form so that we can match up the bank statement when it arrives. It is very important that you include the name of the person receiving the book or subscription and the shipping address. If the address is different on the bank statement- please let us know which is the billing address and which is the shipping address. If Customer Service does not receive the Wire Transfer Form, we may not be able to process your transfer because the bank supplies us with very little information.

Please note that wire transfers can take up to three months to process and deliver.

bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Cosmetics & Toiletries: Editorial

Q. I would like to write an article for one of your publications. Who do I send my article or my synopsis to?

A. You may submit your article to the magazine’s senior editor, Rachel Chapman, at rchapman@allured.com@allured.com. Each magazine web site contains more information about submissions. The magazine site will also give you, the author, insight as to whether or not your submission is suitable to the magazine. Click here to learn more about submitting an article to Cosmetics & Toiletries magazine.

Q. I have a question regarding content of your magazine for research I am doing. Who can I contact?

A. The editors will be more than happy to assist you in answering questions regarding content of the magazine or book. You can e-mail senior editor Rachel Chapman at rchapman@allured.com@allured.com.@allured.com.

If you have a question about a book, please contact Customer Service.

Q. Where can I find a list of organizations for research or for more information?

A. You can find a list of organizations on our website: please visit www.allured.com and click on the magazine site. If you are unable to find what you are looking for, you can e-mail the web editor of the magazine.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Editorial
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Editorial

Q. I would like to write an article for one of your publications. Who do I send my article or my synopsis to?

A. You may submit your article to the magazines' managing editor Jeb Allured at jallured@allured.com. Each magazine web site contains more information about submissions. The magazine sites will also give you, the author, insight as to whether or not your submission is suitable to the magazine.

Click here for Perfumer and Flavorist.

Click here for JEOR.

Q. I have a question regarding content of your magazine for research I am doing. Who can I contact?

A. The editors will be more than happy to assist you in answering questions regarding content of the magazine or book. You can e-mail the magazines' managing editor Jeb Allured at jallured@allured.com.

If you have a question about a book, please contact Customer Service.

Q. Where can I find a list of organizations for research or for more information?

A. You can find a list of organizations on our website: please visit www.allured.com and click on the magazine site. If you are unable to find what you are looking for, you can e-mail the web editor of the magazine.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Book Ordering
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Book Ordering

Q. How do I order your books?

A. There are six ways to order:

  • The simplest, fastest, and most efficient way to order is through our online store, which is a secured site.
  • Call Customer Service direct at 630-653-2155.
  • E-mail Customer Service.
  • Fax Customer Service at 630-653-2487.
  • Mail your order to:
    Allured Publishing Corp.
    362 S Schmale Rd.
    Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787
    c/o Customer Service.
    Include payment and order form or a print out of the on-line order form.
  • The last way to order is by requesting a Proforma Invoice for those products you wish to purchase. Once you return a copy of the Proforma Invoice with your payment, we will ship out your products.

Use e-mail or fax at your own risk when sending credit card information as this is not the recommended way to order. Please choose one way to order and order only once to avoid duplication.

Q. I placed an order for one of your books. Why haven't I heard from you?

A. As much as we would like to confirm each and every order that comes to us, it would be impossible to do so because of the volume we receive on a daily basis. If you do not receive your book after 8 - 10 weeks, we encourage you to e-mail us and let us know. If you placed an order, make sure that you included payment because we will only process your order with prepayment. Please do not send in another order or a copy of your order as it may be entered again and duplicated. More importantly, you will be charged twice because we have no way of knowing if your order is a duplicate.

Q. I ordered a book and received the wrong one. What do I do?

A. We are sorry about that. Please contact Customer Service.

Q. I am an advertiser and have not received my issue of the magazine that I advertised in. Who do I contact?

A. Please contact the editor of the magazine or the account representative.

Q. I am looking for a book, but I cannot locate it on your web site (or no longer have the book on the web site). Do you list all the books you sell?

A. Yes, we do. The web site is the best source of information for the current books we sell. Sometimes the book may be available on the web site one day and may be so popular that it sells out quickly. In this case, we may either send you a letter stating that the book is no longer available and return your payment or back order for you if we know the book is coming soon.

Q. I placed an order for a book. Why didn't you confirm my order?

A. As soon as we receive your payment and order we try to process it same day or next day. We do not confirm orders because of the high volume we receive daily. Please allow for the time it takes for your check to arrive at our office, processing, and delivery time (depending upon what type of delivery you chose). You will only hear from us if your credit card has declined or other reasons such as the book is no longer in stock.

Q. I placed an order for a book and have not received it yet. How long does it take?

A. That depends on what type of delivery option you chose. If you mailed your order and payment to us, please allow time for us to receive your order and processing. If you are located in the U.S., the delivery time is 7-10 business days. If you are international and you chose regular airmail service, your delivery time could take 6-8 weeks and is not trackable. The recommended shipping option for international is to use Courier Service for delivery in 10-15 business days and is trackable.

Q. What is your policy on returning books?

A. Due to the highly technical content of the books, they are sold on a non-refundable, non-returnable basis. We urge our customers to visit our online bookstore for a summary of the book and table of contents. If you have any further questions about the book, please call Customer Service and we will be happy to fax you a few pages from the book if you are uncertain about the content.

Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Magazine Ordering

Q. How do I order a subscription to your magazine?

A. There are six ways to order:

  • The simplest, fastest, and most efficient way to order is through our online store, which is a secured site.
  • Call Customer Service direct at 630-653-2155.
  • E-mail Customer Service.
  • Fax Customer Service at 630-653-2487.
  • Mail your order to:
    Allured Publishing Corp.
    362 S Schmale Rd.
    Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787
    c/o Customer Service.
    Include payment and order form or a print out of the on-line order form.
  • The last way to order is by requesting a Proforma Invoice for those products you wish to purchase. Once you return a copy of the Proforma Invoice with your payment, we will ship out your products.

Use e-mail or fax at your own risk when sending credit card information as this is not the recommended way to order. Please choose one way to order and order only once to avoid duplication.

Q. Can I order specific issues of your magazines?

A.   You can order through Customer Service. If you would like to order a back issue(s), please specify:
  • The Name of the publication.
  • The Month you wish to order.
  • The Year you wish to order.

If you need assistance in determining which issue, please e-mail the editor of the magazine you are interested in. Please allow 2-3 weeks for shipping after payment is received. Back Issues are subject to availability. Prices are subject to change without notice. For all orders please add shipping and handling charges.

Q. I have never seen your magazine. Can you send me a sample issue? Can I request a specific issue?

A. We would be more than happy to send you a sample issue. Please e-mail 
CustomerService@allured.com with the following information:
  • The Name of the publication
  • Your name and complete shipping information
  • Phone Number
  • Business and Function at the company

A specific issue cannot be requested. For your convenience, we will send you an order form along with the sample issue. If you decide not to subscribe, please send back the order form. We would greatly appreciate your feedback and would like to know the reason you have decided not to subscribe. Please allow 4-6 weeks for a sample issue due to the high volume of requests we receive daily.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Payment Options
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Payment Options

Q. What forms of payment do you accept?

A. All orders must be prepayed - you may pay by:

  • Visa
  • Mastercard
  • American Express
  • Check or Money Order
  • For International destinations a check drawn from a US bank in US dollars will be acceptable.
  • Wire transfers - please see details to the right.

Please note: we cannot accept Foreign Checks or Sterling payment.

Q. Why don’t you provide Paid Invoices with every order?

A. We require prepayment on every order, therefore, we are not set up to handle systematic invoicing. If you require a Paid Invoice or a Proforma Invoice, you may request one.

A packing slip/paid invoice is provided with each order for books.

Q. I am an international customer and we do not use credit cards. Can I set up a wire transfer to pay for my subscription?

A. Wire transfers will be accepted in the amount of US$100 or more. The information is as follows:

1. Customers in Europe may pay in US dollars from any bank in Europe via SWIFT (ABNANL2A) transfer into our US dollars account 40.54.19.805 at AMRO BANK, Afd. Zaken, AB 1050, Postbus 407, 1000 AK Amsterdam, Netherlands.

2. All wire transfers may be made through BANK ONE, (071000013), Chicago, Illinois 60690. Our account number is: 20000057.

Please fill out the Wire Transfer form so that we can match up the bank statement when it arrives. It is very important that you include the name of the person receiving the book or subscription and the shipping address. If the address is different on the bank statement- please let us know which is the billing address and which is the shipping address. If Customer Service does not receive the Wire Transfer Form, we may not be able to process your transfer because the bank supplies us with very little information.

Please note that wire transfers can take up to three months to process and deliver.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Claims
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Claims

Q. I have a one year subscription and I am missing an issue/issues. What is your claims policy?

A. Policy: A claims form must be filled out completely and then faxed, e-mailed or mailed to Customer Service, Claims Dept., 362 S. Schmale Rd., Carol Stream, IL 60188-2787. Our fax number is 630.653.2487. Claims for missing issues must be made within three months of the date issued - domestic. For international claims, the claim for missing issues must be made within six months or we will not replace the issues. Please do not wait until the end of the year to place your claims.

We can replace up to three issues per year only once. If an issue is out of print, we cannot replace. Please allow 8-10 weeks to receive issues from the date order or claim is received. If claims are made too early, we cannot replace issues and customer must claim again within a reasonable period of time. If you paid by wire transfer, please note that wire transfers and delivery can take up to three months to complete.

Q. I am not receiving many of the issues even though I paid for a one or two year subscription. What can I do?

A. We are sorry you are not receiving your issues. If you have gone through all the steps (see claims policy) then we suggest that you use an alternative shipping address. You can choose an address of someone you know from the United States or a different country and have your issues forwarded to you.

Q. How soon can I expect my issue to be replaced if I sent in the claim form?

A. You should have a replacement issue in 6-8 weeks providing:

  • Your address is correct.
  • Enough time has passed since the magazine was shipped out.

If the replacement issue does not arrive, perhaps, an alternative address may be the answer.

Q. I e-mailed Customer Service but I have not received an answer yet about my claim.

A. A claims form must be filled out and investigated by Customer Service. We cannot determine whether or not we can replace issues unless the form is completely filled out.

Q. Can you track my issues and find out why we are not receiving issues?

A. Unfortunately, we can only track the issue within the United States. Once it leaves our country, there is no tracking capabilities. In order for us to have tracking capabilities, we would have to substantially raise the cost of the subscription.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Delivery
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Delivery

Q. What are your Delivery Options?

A. In order to serve you better, we are now offering several new options for shipping and handling of your purchases:

  • Courier Service: $40 (Recommended)
    International and Canada only.
    Phone number is required for Courier delivery. No PO Boxes please.
  • International Airmail Service: $15
    Delivery in 6-8 weeks after payment is received.
    We cannot be held responsible for lost or stolen articles shipped via International Airmail.
  • Canadian Delivery: $10
    Standard delivery in 7-10 business days after payment is received.
    Phone number is required for delivery. No PO Boxes please.
  • United States Delivery: $8
    Standard delivery in 7-10 business days after payment is received.
    Phone number is required for delivery. No PO Boxes please.

Note: We do not recommend International Airmail for $15 because it can take up to 12 weeks for delivery.

Please indicate the type of service you require on your order form, and include payment with your order.

Q. I chose International Airmail for $15.00. Why is delivery taking so long?

A. This is regular airmail and not courier service. This means that the delivery is not trackable and can be routed through several countries before it reaches you. There are cases where a book can take 12 weeks to reach international destinations. We cannot be held responsible for lost or stolen articles on this type of service. If you would like to receive your books within a reasonable length of time, please choose Courier Service which is more money, but we are able to guarantee delivery of your order.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Address/Name Change
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Address/Name Change

Q. If I move, who do I contact about my change of address?

A. We don’t want you to miss an issue! You may contact Customer Service for any address change by clicking here. Don’t forget to notify your local post office of the change of address. We ask that you give us at least 30 –60 days notification so that you receive the issue at your new address if the post office is not forwarding your mail. In some cases, the issue has already been sent out to the old address and you may ‘claim’ the issue. Please see the Customer Service Claims Page and follow that procedure for a quicker response.

Q. There is a name change at my company - how do I change the name that appears on my current subscription?

A. If there is a name change on a company account, we would like this in writing on company stationary for our records. Please include the subscription number which is found on the address label beside or above the name.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Accounts Payable
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: Accounts Payable

Q. I received my credit card statement and there is a charge here from Allured Publishing. What is this for?

A. You may have charged a magazine subscription, magazine single copy, book, attended a conference or show and charged the entry fee, paid for a class at Face & Body or paid for advertising. Those charges show up as Allured Publishing, not as the individual product you may have purchased.

Q. I recently subscribed to your magazine and I have a question about the charge on my credit card statement. Who do I contact?

A. Account Receivable for Subscriptions is handled by Customer Service. Please supply us with complete details such as:

  • the dollar amount that was charged.
  • the date the amount was processed.
  • mail us a copy of your statement.

Please explain why you are disputing the amount.

Q. Why is there a duplicate charge on my credit card statement?

A. The reason may be because you sent in more than one payment. We process each order we receive. To avoid duplication, please do not, for instance, fax in an order with a credit card payment, and then mail in the order with a credit card payment. We process each order because there are many instances where customers wish to purchase more than one book or to add another copy of a subscription for the year. If you find a duplicate payment that you did not intend to purchase, please bring this to our attention and we will refund the charge.

Q. I paid one amount for my subscription but when I cancelled I was refunded only a portion of my payment. Why?

A. Because we refund on all unserved issues only. If you paid for a one year subscription to one of our magazines, and then cancel several months later, the unserved issues are refunded only. Also, we would appreciate hearing why you cancelled and we encourage any comments you may have.

name: CSI: Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: General Questions
bodyOriginal:
Customer Service Information:
Perfumer & Flavorist and JEOR: General Questions

Q. I e-mailed Customer Service but I have not received an answer yet. What is taking so long?

A. Customer Service receives a great deal of e-mail on a daily basis. Some questions can be answered quickly. Other questions require further investigation by the department such as claims or wire transfer questions and may take a little longer to reply or may have to be forwarded to other departments. We will do our best to reply as quickly as possible. Claims and shipping concerns are processed on a weekly basis and your patience is greatly appreciated. If you do not hear from us within a reasonable length of time, please e-mail us again. There are times when e-mails directed to Customer Service are not received due to any number of reasons and there are times when we respond to e-mails only to discover the e-mails were never received. Allured Publishing deems each e-mail important and we will do our best to reply as quickly as possible and satisfy our customers.

Q. I would like to receive a catalog of your books and magazines. Who can I contact?

A. For book information please feel free to visit our online bookstore. Here you will find an updated list of all our products, with descriptions and a table of contents.

For magazine information, please visit the magazine sites, where you will find a great deal of information.

Click here for Perfumer and Flavorist.

Click here for JEOR.

Q. Why don't you provide Paid Invoices with every order?

A. We require prepayment on every order, therefore, we are not set up to handle systematic invoicing. If you require a Paid Invoice or a Proforma Invoice, you may request one. We provide a packing slip/paid invoice for each order.

Sales & Marketing Manager
Spherix, the company that invented and developed tagatose (NaturloseTM),  is looking for a Manager/Director of Sales and Marketing to lead its sales of this revolutionary new sweetener into the Pharmaceutical/Healthcare/Cosmetics industries for non-food uses.

Responsibilities to include:

  • Optimizing existing and new
    sales materials.
  • Prioritize existing and new customer list.
  • Contact existing and new customers and close deals.
  • Develop customer relationships.
  • Work with management to develop new business opportunities.

Candidates must have 10+years proven successful track record of selling food ingredients to the non-food, cosmetic, OTC/RX markets.  Must be a self starter, an excellent communicator and a builder of customer relationships. Must be a deal closer.  Experience in selling polyols and other low-calorie sweeteners preferred.  Must be willing to travel significantly and must possess a BS/MBA.  (Food Technologies and/or life sciences preferred)

Spherix Incorporated
Ph: 301-419-3900 · Fx: 301-623-2330
hrdept@spherix.com



Express your creative talents with the research team at Creative Nail Design, an internationally known manufacturer of professional beauty products.  Creative Nail Design is looking for an experienced chemist in cosmetic/skin care product development.  BS in Science or minimum 3 years experience in related field. Salaried position, fully equipped state-of-the-art research lab, great benefits, 401(k) & bonus. EOE. Fax resume with salary history to 760-599-1267, ATTN: HR Department.


COLETICA INC., the North American affiliate of the French-based parent company COLETICA S.A, is looking to hire a new Account Manager.

COLETICA is a worldwide leader in the skin care actives field, with a high level of technology in encapsulation, molecular coupling, biotechnology and tissue engineering. The candidate will justify of a technical background (B.S in Chemistry, Biology…) and of 3-5 years in sales (in the cosmetic industry is a plus).

The Account Manager will cover territories including the Midwest, Canada, Mexico and the NY-NJ area and serve small to large customers. The candidate will be results driven, customer oriented, and a real team player with a strong commitment.

Enthusiastic, organized, self-motivated, he/she will be able to make technical and marketing presentations. This position will be based in New York, NY and involve frequent traveling (North America and France, mainly.)

Please send your resume with your letter exclusively by email to:
Tony Jaillot - Chief Operating Officer - tjaillot@coletica.com

name: Photoaging and Photodocumentation
bodyOriginal: An image conveys an immediate and powerful message, both to the "untrained" consumer and to the expert grader. A comparison of two images, such as before and after treatment, creates an even stronger statement. Therefore, significant attention has been given to the standardization of imaging and photographic tools in order to use images as part of scientific evaluation methods in acne and photoaging.

name: Technically Speaking
bodyOriginal:
Skin and Skin Care
Stratum corneum acidification: Fluhr et al. report that the generation of free fatty acids form phospholipids regulates the stratum corneum acidification and integrity.

Although first recognized several decades ago, the origin and function of the "acid mantle" of the stratum corneum (SC) remains conjectural.

name: Using Silicones to Formulate Bath Products for Tropical Climates
bodyOriginal: As with many personal care products, regional preferences related to product type and sensory effect help shape trends in the global marketplace. The bath and shower segment in Asia is no exception, reflecting a longtime preference for soap bars, a growing interest in shower gels and tactile inclination toward products that leave a soft, moisturized feel with little reidue. At least in part, these aesthetic preferences can be linked to tropical climates in the Asian region.

name: PFPE Phosphate: A Multifunctional Material
bodyOriginal:
Chemical modification of the Z-type perfluoropolyether by introducing phosphate groups yields a multifunctional material useful for preparing aqueous solutions, hydrogels and emulsions. IN this article, we discuss the material's formulation guidelines, and report results of tests on its water/oil repellency, its water resistance, its skin irritation and its antimicrobial activity.

Download the complete article.

name: Castor Polyesters for Personal Care
bodyOriginal: This article describes a series of polymers based on the naturally occurring castor oil and succinic acid, reacted to make a polyester (such as castor succinate) and then functionalized to provide benefits in cosmetic formulations. Several formulations are provided to demonstrate the use of the various castor succinate polyester compounds.

name: Preservation of "Atypical" Cosmetic Product Systems
bodyOriginal:
We can loosely define "atypical" cosmetic products as those product forms that do not naturally conform to the "typical" o/w formulation characteristics exhibited by the vast majority of cosmetic products currently on the market.

Over the years, there has been considerable controversy regarding both the general philosophy of needing to preserve atypical products and, if the need is considered to be valid, how to accomplish this without artificially disrupting the integrity of the product system under evaluation.

name: Testing for Dioxin and Furan Contamination in Triclosan
bodyOriginal: Triclosan is a broad-specrum antibacterial/antimicrobial agent first introduced commercially more than 30 years ago. Measuring Synergy
bodyOriginal:
The New Merriam-Webster Pocket Dictionary defines synergism as "a joint action of discrete agencies in which the total effect is greater than the sum of their effects when acting independently. The most common area in cosmetics where we hear this term is in preservation.

Synergism is of great interest in ipreserving cosmetics. As we must protect against many different Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria, yeast and molds, it is rare to find a single preservative that is sufficiently broad spectrum to accomplish this task. The use of multiple preservatives is a comon way to accomplish this purpose. Their use is usually additive, but could also be synergistic or even antagonistic.

name: "Precautionary" Regulation Genetics and Cosmeceuticals in the 21st Century
bodyOriginal: The 21st century will increasingly see regulators implementing a "recautionary approach" to risks posed by cosmetics. The precautionary approach is a step beyond traditional risk assessment in that is assumes that a biologically active agent will cause harm until the producer conducts enough tests to prove it to be safe. This contrasts to risk assessment that allows a manufacturer to assume safety based on "state-of-the-art" testing methods (e.g., animal tests) that prove safety to the satisfaction of most "mainstream" scientists.

name: Topical Formulations Conforming to the Structure of the Skin
bodyOriginal:
Oneof the most important prerequisites of healthy skin is the intactness of its lipid permeability barrier--a unique stack of bilayers assembled in the epidermis from a mixture of biomolecules. But topical formulations that include emulsifiers attach that barrier.

The function of emulsifiers in skin care products is to disperse lipids contianed in the formulations. However, when these emulsifiers disperse lipids of the permeability barrier, the continuous stacked-bilayer structure is either damaged or destroyed. The extent of the interaction is the function of the emulsfiers' chemical structure and dosage in a given products.

name: New Laminin Peptide for Innovative Skin Care Cosmetics
bodyOriginal:
Epidermal basement membrane is a specialized cutaneous zone of extracellular matrix (ECM) that separates the epidermis from the dermis. The membrane, however, serves more than simple structural and filtering roles.

The basement membrane contains specific structures that ensure the stability of the connection and communication between the two major skin compartments, the epidermis and the dermis. Among these structures we find different molecules, such as collagen IV and laminin.

Laminin represents a family of diverse critical multifunctional molecules, and is a very important component of the extracellular matrix. Laminin plays a critical role in cell behavior, is a potent cell adhesion molecule, and its defects are involved in some skin pathologies.

Laminin is an essential constituent of the basement membrane and plays a primordial role together with the basement membrane in cell communication, adhesion and cutaneous regeneration. Moreover, recent studies have confirmed the involvement of the basement membrane in skin aging due to the early alteration of the membrane’s constituents during the aging process.

Therefore, we were interested in developing a lamininlike peptide for topical skin care and cosmetics. In this paper, we describe in vitro studies concerning the properties of the new laminin peptide and its effects on human skin cells.

Laminin is made of multidomain glycoproteins and is thus directly involved in many biological functions. To date, many laminin isoforms have been identified. They are large disulfide-bonded heterotrimers composed of three genetically distinct polypeptide chains: alpha, beta, and gamma. For the complete article, click on "Purchase this article."

name: CTFA Preservative Challenge and Stability Testing Survey
bodyOriginal:
Preservatives are included in most finished cosmetic product formulations to protect them from microbiological contamination during normal consumer use. This protection must continue for the expected shelf life of the finished cosmetic product. A microbiological challenge test is performed to evaluate the effectiveness of a preservative system against normal microbiological contamination during the shelf life of a finished product.

In 1999, The Cosmetic, Toiletry, and Fragrance Association (CTFA) surveyed member companies for the purpose of determining what practices for preservative and stability testing are used by the cosmetic industry. The survey was designed to:

• Gather current information from the cosmetic industry on challenge test methods, stability test conditions and preservative adequacy acceptance criteria as applied to cosmetic and toiletry formulations;

• Qualitatively compare the survey findings to the findings of an unpublished preservative stability testing survey that was conducted in 1986;

 • Inform the cosmetic microbiologist of current industry practices for preservative challenge and preservative stability testing of cosmetic and toiletry formulations.

The survey consisted of 28 questions ranging from preservative challenge testing to stability test conditions. Questionnaires were sent to CTFA active and associate member companies. The information reported here was provided by 39 companies who manufacture fi nished cosmetic products. The survey did not determine what kinds of cosmetic products the respondents produced, and it did not determine if the products contained added preservatives. All responses were coded to avoid disclosure of company identifi cation and to protect proprietary information.

name: Pigments as Photoprotectants
bodyOriginal:
Pigments are solid particles and are insoluble in water and fatty matter. They may be classified into two groups, depending on their origin: mineral pigments, which are of mineral origin, and organic pigments, which are produced by organic sythesis.

Mineral pigments are inert and opaque powders that reflect and diffuse UV radiation and part of the visible light (Figure 1). Consequently, they provide broad-spectrum protection. The mineral pigments most often used for photoprotection are titanium dioxide (TiO2) and zinc oxide (ZnO). Other elements such as zirconium, cerium, talc and kaolin are less used because their capacity to attenuate UV radiation is low. This article will focus on the protectant properties of TiO2 and ZnO.

Titanium is one of the 10 most abundant elements on earth. It can be found as mineral rutile (93-97% titanium dioxide) or in conjunction with iron oxides in the ores such as ilmente (45- 75% titanium dioxide). It makes up 0.6% of the earth’s crust and can be found either in its pure state or combined with ferrous oxide.

Zinc is also found in large quantities on earth, although it is less abundant than titanium. Its principal ores are blend (sulfide), smithsonite (carbonate), calamine (silicate) and franklinite (zinc, manganese and iron oxide). It can be found as zinc salt (carbonate, silica) or combined with other metals such as manganese or ferrous oxide.

name: A Review of Current Sunscreen Formulation Techniques and Technology
bodyOriginal:
Developing a modern sunscreen formulation requires a good mix of science and art. Sunscreen products are now far more efficient, cost effective, water resistant, elegant and safe than the choices available a few short years ago. However, one must not overlook the input of our marketing friends. They are the ones who often identify or create the trends that send us back to our laboratory benches for a scientific hocus-pocus.

This article includes ingredient listings for several popular sunscrenn products recently sold by major manufacturers in the United States. I will analyze each of these products and attempt to uncover the rationale for the use of the major components.

name: A New Photostablizer for Full Spectrum Sunscreen
bodyOriginal: In this article, we, the authors, advocate a non-traditional approach to sunscreen design, one that aims at providing full spectrum sun protection by attenuating at least 90% of all solar UV radiation. We introduce diethylhexyl 2,6-naphthalate (DEHN), a new chemical additive for sunscreens developed in the laboratories of C.P. Hall, and we present experimental data showing the photostabilizing effect of this chemical on sunscreens containing the widely-used UV filter, avobenzone. We discuss the photochemistry of sunscreen photostability, the approach to sunscreen design. Finally, we present sunscreen formulations that incorporate DEHN and we show the results of both in vitro and in vivo studies of their performance.

name: Cigarette Smoking and Skin Biomarkers
bodyOriginal: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimate that smoking kills approximately 400,000 people in the United States yearly. Cigarette smoking is the nation's leading cause of premature mortality and is responsible for one-third of all deaths among working-age Americans. Cardiovascular disease is the most common cause of excess mortality among younger smokers. Therefore, tobacco-related cardiovascular disease has been extensively investigated. However, tobacco-related cutaneous morbidity is less investigated. Some research has been documented as to the damaging effects of smoking on the skin vasculature and on oxygenation in both human and animal models.

name: Formulating Conditioning Shampoos
bodyOriginal:
Early attempts at conditioning shampoos sought to include liquid oleoresin from wood in products that were dubbed balsam shampoos. A two-phase shampoo was introduced that consisted of a mineral oil layer floating on top of an aqueous detergent layer, with an alkyl alcohol as an emulsion destabilizer. This product was designed to deposity the oily material during the shampooing process.

However, wood rosin was difficult to formulate in a stable homogenous shampoo. It tended to flocculate, coagulate and separate from the composition. Wood rosin deposited on hair because it was imcompatible with dilute shampoo and it was sticky. Unfortunately, these "attricutes" also caused the rosin to build up on the hair with successive shampoo cycles and this was unpopular with consumers.

name: Correlating Porosity and Tensile Strength of Chemically Modified Hair
bodyOriginal:
Over the years, many individual studies have been conducted regarding the extent of damage imparted to hair. These studies deal with the damaging effects of various chemical processes such as permanent waves, permanent colors and hair bleaches.

The most commonly employed method to quantify this damage is the measurement of change in tensile properties of the hair. This method takes two to three days in the preparation of samples of hair fibers. It also requires a minimum of 30 to 40 fibers for statistical analysis. Therefore, there is a need for other simpler methods that are equally valid and less time-consuming.

name: Canadian Environmental Protection Act and Its Personal Care Implications
bodyOriginal:
The regulatory scene for chemicals in Canada has been changing considerably during the past several years, and current developments have the potential to profoundly impact the cosmetics and toiletries sector in Canada and abroad. Existing and new substances, either manufactured or imported into Canada, are governed by the Canadian Environmental Protection Act (CEPA) and its New Substance Notification Regulations (NSNR). The implementation of the NSNR is shared by Environment Canada and Health Canada.

When CEPA first went into effect in 1988, ingredients used in products regulated under the Food and Drugs Act (F&DA) were administratively exempted. During the late 1990s, CEPA was subjected to a Parliamentary Review, and the outcome was a revised CEPA known as CEPA99, which removed the exemption for F&DA ingredients. The NSNR were first implemented in July 1994, a product of multi-stakeholder consultations.

name: Polyquaternium-55: A New Force in Styling Products
bodyOriginal:
Many regionso f the world are experiencing an increased number of consumers who express themselves with enhanced hairstyles, especially with hair color and "chameleon" styling. These men and women work with their hair on a regular basis and have a keen awareness of the condition of their hair. They see that the more their hair is treated, whether chemically, by sun exposure, swimming or mechanical grooming (towel drying, blow-drying, hot irons, braiding, etc.), the more damaged and difficult to style and handle the hair becomes. The consumer doesn't need amino acid or tensile analysis to measure the extent of damage; they can "feel" the effect of damage on their hair iwht just their hands or brush during every stage of styling from shampooing, through conditioning, styling and finishing.

Polyquaternium-55 is a multifunctional and hydrophobically modified polymer to provide a smooth, moisturized feel.

name: Surface-Active Phospholipids for Personal Care
bodyOriginal:
During the last 25 years, a great deal of work has been done to develop surface-active agents that contain phosphorous. This is due in part to the natural occurrence of phospholipids, a chemical necessary for life as we know it. Synthetic phosphorous-based surface-active agents can provide a number of properties to formulations including wetting, emulsifi cation, foaming, conditioning and having antimicrobial properties.

While there is no single compound with all of these various properties, the properties are a direct consequence of the structure of the compounds. There are three very different classes of phosphorus-based compounds with different properties. These include the mild, high-foaming, detergent molecules called phosphobetaines; the emollient conditioning compounds, which have become known as phospholipids; and the antimicrobial super conditioning agents called phosphoquats.

This article offers a review of the chemistry of natural phospholipids, synthetic phospholipids, phosphobetaines and phosphoquats. Naturally occurring lipids are actually triglycerides made by the reaction of a fatty acid and glycerin. These materials can be made in the laboratory with catalyst at a high temperature (180-200°C). However, the reaction occurs in living cells at low temperatures using specifi c enzyme systems (Figure 1).

The pH of the Stratum Corneum: An Update
bodyOriginal:
About 10 years ago, I attempted to explain some of the features of pH measurements on the skin's surface. At that time, common knowledge accepted that alkaline substances, (soaps), applied to the skin might elicit adverse skin effects and that skin cleansing with neutral surfactants might be preferable. Questions about this simplistic concept, pH dependence of skin irritation, are documented in the literature.

The picture was further obscured by the classical attribution of the merits to the skin's so-called acid mantle. Since that time, investigators in skin physiology have avoided the controversy of potential skin damage by exposure to mildly alkaline substance. The most recent studies reported here describe newly discovered phenomena involved in pH changes during terminal differentiation, therefore, the earlier veiw is in need of updating.

name: Avoiding Transdermal Cosmetic Delivery
bodyOriginal:
Key words: cosmetic delivery, transdermal, skin penetration, liposomes

Abstract: The author describes the delivery concept, the skin’s penetration routes, penetration measurement methods, and examples of systems to deliver functional ingredients to the epidermal layer only.

In the mind of most cosmetic chemists, the words “transdermal” and “cosmetic” should not be mentioned in the same sentence. The reason for this is that cosmetic scientists generally do not want their cosmetic ingredients to penetrate all the way through the skin into the systemic circulation. Nevertheless, the term “cosmetic delivery” is gradually being used more frequently in cosmetic research. Interestingly, this trend is following the increased use of functional ingredients and it will become evident that this is not coincidental. The objective of this paper is to identify what “delivery” means, to assess its relevance for cosmetic science and to give examples of how this knowledge may help to create better cosmetic products in the marketplace. But the first question to ask ourselves is, why do we need it?

The efficacy of any product containing a functional ingredient is determined by two factors: a) the intrinsic activity of the active molecule, and b) the delivery of this molecule to its site of action. The intrinsic activity, or the capability to do something, is dictated by the functionality profile of an active ingredient, but does not guarantee that every product containing this functional ingredient is indeed functional. For the functionality to emerge, the active ingredient needs to be delivered to the site of action at relevant concentrations for a sufficiently long period of time to do its work.

These functionality considerations apply to all types of active materials in a range of products. For example, hair conditioners need to be deposited onto the hair to do their work. On the other hand, skin lighteners need to penetrate the skin to inhibit the tyrosinase enzyme in melanogenesis. The overall efficacy of a product containing a functional ingredient is therefore the result of multiplying the intrinsic activity of the ingredient and its delivery. Both activity and delivery need to be optimized to obtain an effective product.

While transdermal delivery is relatively well understood, the main factors affecting dermal delivery are still unknown, due to the difficulty of measuring dermal delivery. Therefore, it is not surprising to see that transdermal delivery systems are used to promote dermal delivery. However, from a safety point of view it is questionable whether using technology that is aimed at increasing the flow of active ingredient across the skin is the right technology to ensure the highest retention of functional ingredient in the skin. I titled this paper “Avoiding Transdermal Cosmetic Delivery,” with this in mind.

 

For the complete article, click on "Purchase this article."

name: The Wipe: A Carrier of Skin Benefits
bodyOriginal:
Wet wipes in the personal care area are a relatively new and quickly developing product category. In this article, we review the functions, history and benefits of wet wipes. We also describe methods of assessing clinical benefit in two areas: gentle infant skin cleaning and sunscreen efficacy.

What Is a Wipe?

A wet wipe for personal-care use is typically constructed from a substrate material, a lotion and a container. Figure 1 demonstrates these different parts of a wipe along with their key functions. Both the substrate and lotion have changed since wet wipes were introduced more than 30 years ago (see sidebar).

Modern substrate materials are often combinations of many fiber types, including synthetic (e.g. polyolefin), viscose, cotton and cellulose, chosen to achieve desired tactile properties. Fibers are formed into strong, tear-resistant wipe substrates using a variety of technologies for non-woven materials. Chemical binder materials are sometimes included to add strength.

name: The Safety Factor in Preservative Efficacy Testing
bodyOriginal:
Aqueous consumer products in multiple-use containers need a preservative system to prevent microbial contamination during manufacturing and consumer use, and to comply with governmental regulations. Preservative effi cacy testing is performed to determine the type and minimum effective concentration of preservative(s) required for satisfactory preservation of these products.

In its Cosmetics Handbook under “Adequacy of Preservation,” the FDA recommends that: (a) each batch of a cosmetic which is not self-preserving be tested for microbial contamination before it is released for interstate shipment; and (b) each cosmetic, particularly each eye area cosmetic, be tested during product development for adequacy of preservation against microbial contamination that may occur under reasonably foreseeable conditions of consumer use.

The European Union’s Cosmetic Directive states that all cosmetics must have in their product information package (“dossier”) the microbiological specifi cations of the raw materials and the fi nished product; the dossier must also disclose the purity and the microbiological control criteria of the cosmetic product. Preservative effi cacy test methods include the following:

• Compendial methods, such as the United States Pharmacopoeia (USP) and European Pharmacopoeia (EP) methods;

• Trade association methods, such as the Cosmetic, Toiletry, and Fragrance Association (CTFA) method; and

 • Rapid methods, such as the linear regression method. Several articles have discussed similarities and differences in these test methods. Orth, Delgadillo and Dumatol reported that the slower rates of death allowed by both the USP and CTFA methods may be too lenient.

name: Cosmetic Testing in 2000 and Beyond
bodyOriginal:
As a child, my confidence in the advice given by fortune-tellers at fairs was so limited that I refused to visit these ladies. So, it is with mixed feelings that I write about the future of cosmetic testing in 2000 and beyond. After all, I could be the fortune-teller at the Vanity Fair of Cosmetics!

But in contrast to fortune-tellers, who used only their vivid imaginations, as far as I am concerned, I am basing my predictions on three different souces. My first source is the cosmetic scientific literature; second, some trend spotting from attending trade fairs; and lastly, technology forecasting borrowed from some of the newer technologies used in the pharmaceutical industry.

name: Claim Support Literature Review-Part IV, Skin Physiology and Properties
bodyOriginal:
As I mentioned earlier in this series, when claims are made for marketed products, they are usually supported by appropriate professionally recognized studies, which are executed by professionally recognized personnel, either in-house or at outside facilities. However, in many cases, claims can be supported by referring to studies published in peer reviewed and professionally recognized scientific journals. In this respect, I thought it would be useful to product development scientists as well as to marketing personnel to bring to your attention pertinent literature references that could be useful in developing or reinforcing certain claims or in developing new products.

A deficiency in the peripheral microcirculation can be a contributing factor in the poor appearance of aging skin, and the topical application of materials that enhance the microcirculation can be useful in enhancing facial appearance. Cristoni et al. states that Ginkgo biloba leaf extract is probably one of the most investigated among natural ingredients clinically employed by the systemic route to improve the peripheral circulation, but little has been reported on the efficacy of such extracts after topical application.

name: Measured Dermal Effect of Applying Retin-A
bodyOriginal: Skin is organized horizontally into three distinct layers: epidermis, dermis, and the subcutis. The epidermis is a layer of stratified squamous epithelium that is keratinized. The second layer, the dermis, consists of a complex fibrous matrix set into a mucopolysaccharide gel infiltrated with blood vessels, lymphatic channels, nerves, glandularw ducts and hair follicles. The third layer, the subcutis, is populated primarily by adipocyted. The research reported here focuses on the dermis because it is the site of the primary water retention molecule, hyaluronic acid (HA) in the skin.
